title: Zambia: Zambia's Crediting Rating Downgraded to Five Steps Below Investment Grade
text:
Zambia's Crediting Rating Downgraded to Five Steps Below Investment Grade Tagged: Zambia: Due to Loadshedding, Wheat Production to Drop Massively - Znfu 
Moody's Investors Service downgraded its credit rating for Zambia citing lower growth and an extended period of weak commodity prices. 
Zambia's rating was cut one level to B2, five steps below investment grade. Growth will fall below 5% for first time since 2002, report says. 
Due to poor leadership at national level, Zambia is grappling with its worst-ever power shortage and metal prices that have fallen to six-year lows, prompting companies including Glencore Plc to halt operations. The kwacha has fallen 41 percent against the dollar this year, the worst performance among the world's currencies. 
"The key driver for the downgrade is our expectation that the trend of persistent fiscal deficits and deterioration in debt metrics witnessed over the past few years is likely to continue," Moody's analyst Matt Robinson wrote in an e-mailed report. "An extended period of weak commodity prices, constrained copper production, and domestic electricity shortages" are hurting business activity, he wrote. 
Yields on Zambia's $1.25 billion Eurobonds maturing in 2027 have climbed to 11.4 percent from 9.4 percent when they were sold in July. 
Moody's held its rating of Zambia's foreign debt at B1 in May while changing the outlook to negative from stable. Glencore's decision to suspend output in the country threatened growth the government forecast would reach 5 percent this year, the company said in a report this month. 
Standard & Poor's on Friday affirmed its B rating on Zambia, also five steps below investment grade Zambia
